11.verse: One of Joab’s young officers shouted to Amasa’s troops, “If you are for David, come and follow Joab.”

12.verse: But Amasa lay in his blood in the middle of the road, and when Joab’s young officers saw that a crowd was gathering around to stare at him, they dragged him off the road into a field and threw a garment over him.

13.verse: With the body out of the way, everyone went on with Joab to capture Sheba.

14.verse: Meanwhile Sheba had traveled across Israel to mobilize his own clan of Bichri at the city of Abel in Beth-maacah.

15.verse: When Joab’s forces arrived, they besieged Abel and built a mound to the top of the city wall and began battering it down.

16.verse: But a wise woman in the city called out to Joab, “Listen to me, Joab. Come over here so I can talk to you.”

17.verse: As he approached, the woman asked, “Are you Joab?” And he replied, “I am.”

18.verse: So she told him, “There used to be a saying, ‘If you want to settle an argument, ask advice at Abel.’ For we always give wise counsel.

19.verse: You are destroying an ancient, peace-loving city, loyal to Israel. Should you destroy what is the Lord’s?”

20.verse: And Joab replied, “That isn’t it at all.

21.verse: All I want is a man named Sheba from the hill country of Ephraim, who has revolted against King David. If you will deliver him to me, we will leave the city in peace.” “All right,” the woman replied, “we will throw his head over the wall to you.”

22.verse: Then the woman went to the people with her wise advice, and they cut off Sheba’s head and threw it out to Joab. And he blew the trumpet and called his troops back from the attack, and they returned to the king at Jerusalem.

23.verse: Joab was commander-in-chief of the army, and Benaiah was in charge of the king’s bodyguard.

24.verse: Adoram was in charge of the forced labor battalions, and Jehoshaphat was the historian who kept the records.

25.verse: Sheva was the secretary, and Zadok and Abiathar were the chief priests.

26.verse: Ira the Jairite was David’s personal chaplain.

1.verse: There was a famine during David’s reign that lasted year after year for three years, and David spent much time in prayer about it. Then the Lord said, “The famine is because of the guilt of Saul and his family, for they murdered the Gibeonites.”

2.verse: So King David summoned the Gibeonites. They were not part of Israel but were what was left of the nation of the Amorites. Israel had sworn not to kill them; but Saul, in his nationalistic zeal, had tried to wipe them out.

3.verse: David asked them, “What can I do for you to rid ourselves of this guilt and to induce you to ask God to bless us?”

4.verse: “Well, money won’t do it,” the Gibeonites replied, “and we don’t want to see Israelites executed in revenge.” “What can I do, then?” David asked. “Just tell me and I will do it for you.”

5.verse: “Well, then,” they replied, “give us seven of Saul’s sons—the sons of the man who did his best to destroy us. We will hang them before the Lord in Gibeon, the city of King Saul.” “All right,” the king said, “I will do it.”

6.verse: “Well, then,” they replied, “give us seven of Saul’s sons—the sons of the man who did his best to destroy us. We will hang them before the Lord in Gibeon, the city of King Saul.” “All right,” the king said, “I will do it.”

7.verse: He spared Jonathan’s son Mephibosheth, who was Saul’s grandson, because of the oath between himself and Jonathan.

8.verse: But he gave them Saul’s two sons Armoni and Mephibosheth, whose mother was Rizpah, the daughter of Aiah. He also gave them the five adopted sons of Michal that she brought up for Saul’s daughter Merab, the wife of Adriel.

9.verse: The men of Gibeon impaled them in the mountain before the Lord. So all seven of them died together at the beginning of the barley harvest.

10.verse: Then Rizpah, the mother of two of the men, spread sackcloth upon a rock and stayed there through the entire harvest season* to prevent the vultures from tearing at their bodies during the day and the wild animals from eating them at night.

11.verse: When David learned what she had done,

12.verse: he arranged for the men’s bones to be buried in the grave of Saul’s father, Kish. At the same time he sent a request to the men of Jabesh-gilead, asking them to bring him the bones of Saul and Jonathan. They had stolen their bodies from the public square at Beth-shan where the Philistines had impaled them after they had died in battle on Mount Gilboa. So their bones were brought to him. Then at last God answered prayer and ended the famine.

15.verse: Once when the Philistines were at war with Israel, and David and his men were in the thick of the battle, David became weak and exhausted.

16.verse: Ishbi-benob, a giant whose speartip weighed more than twelve pounds and who was sporting a new suit of armor, closed in on David and was about to kill him.

17.verse: But Abishai, the son of Zeruiah, came to his rescue and killed the Philistine. After that David’s men declared, “You are not going out to battle again! Why should we risk snuffing out the light of Israel?”

18.verse: Later, during a war with the Philistines at Gob, Sibbecai the Hushathite killed Saph, another giant.

19.verse: At still another time and at the same place, Elhanan killed the brother of Goliath the Gittite, whose spear handle was as huge as a weaver’s beam!

20.verse: And once when the Philistines and the Israelis were fighting at Gath, a giant with six fingers on each hand and six toes on each foot defied Israel, and David’s nephew Jonathan—the son of David’s brother Shimei—killed him.

1.verse: David sang this song to the Lord after he had rescued him from Saul and from all his other enemies:

2.verse: “Jehovah is my rock, My fortress and my savior.

3.verse: I will hide in God, Who is my rock and my refuge. He is my shield And my salvation, My refuge and high tower. Thank you, O my Savior, For saving me from all my enemies.

4.verse: I will call upon the Lord, Who is worthy to be praised; He will save me from all my enemies.

5.verse: The waves of death surrounded me; Floods of evil burst upon me;

6.verse: I was trapped and bound By hell and death;

7.verse: But I called upon the Lord in my distress, And he heard me from his Temple. My cry reached his ears.

8.verse: Then the earth shook and trembled; The foundations of the heavens quaked Because of his wrath.

9.verse: Smoke poured from his nostrils; Fire leaped from his mouth And burned up all before him, Setting fire to the world.

10.verse: He bent the heavens down and came to earth; He walked upon dark clouds.

11.verse: He rode upon the glorious— On the wings of the wind.

12.verse: Darkness surrounded him, And clouds were thick around him;

13.verse: The earth was radiant with his brightness.

14.verse: The Lord thundered from heaven; The God above all gods gave out a mighty shout.

15.verse: He shot forth his arrows of lightning And routed his enemies.

16.verse: By the blast of his breath Was the sea split in two. The bottom of the sea appeared.

17.verse: From above, he rescued me. He drew me out from the waters;

18.verse: He saved me from powerful enemies, From those who hated me And from those who were too strong for me.

19.verse: They came upon me In the day of my calamity, But the Lord was my salvation.

20.verse: He set me free and rescued me, For I was his delight.

21.verse: The Lord rewarded me for my goodness, For my hands were clean;

22.verse: And I have not departed from my God.

23.verse: I knew his laws, And I obeyed them.

24.verse: I was perfect in obedience And kept myself from sin.

25.verse: That is why the Lord has done so much for me, For he sees that I am clean.

26.verse: You are merciful to the merciful; You show your perfections To the blameless.

27.verse: To those who are pure, You show yourself pure; But you destroy those who are evil.

28.verse: You will save those in trouble, But you bring down the haughty; For you watch their every move.

29.verse: O Lord, you are my light! You make my darkness bright.

30.verse: By your power I can crush an army; By your strength I leap over a wall.

31.verse: As for God, his way is perfect; The word of the Lord is true. He shields all who hide behind him.

32.verse: Our Lord alone is God; We have no other Savior.

33.verse: God is my strong fortress; He has made me safe.

34.verse: He causes the good to walk a steady tread Like mountain goats upon the rocks.

35.verse: He gives me skill in war And strength to bend a bow of bronze.

36.verse: You have given me the shield of your salvation; Your gentleness has made me great.

37.verse: You have made wide steps for my feet, To keep them from slipping.

38.verse: I have chased my enemies And destroyed them. I did not stop till all were gone.

39.verse: I have destroyed them So that none can rise again. They have fallen beneath my feet.

40.verse: For you have given me strength for the battle And have caused me to subdue All those who rose against me.

41.verse: You have made my enemies Turn and run away; I have destroyed them all.

42.verse: They looked in vain for help; They cried to God, But he refused to answer.

43.verse: I beat them into dust; I crushed and scattered them Like dust along the streets.

44.verse: You have preserved me From the rebels of my people; You have preserved me As the head of the nations. Foreigners shall serve me

45.verse: And shall quickly submit to me When they hear of my power.

46.verse: They shall lose heart And come, trembling, From their hiding places.

47.verse: The Lord lives. Blessed be my Rock. Praise to him— The Rock of my salvation.

48.verse: Blessed be God Who destroys those who oppose me

49.verse: And rescues me from my enemies. Yes, you hold me safe above their heads. You deliver me from violence.

50.verse: No wonder I give thanks to you, O Lord, among the nations, And sing praises to your name.

51.verse: He gives wonderful deliverance to his king And shows mercy to his anointed— To David and his family, Forever.”

1.verse: These are the last words of David: “David, the son of Jesse, speaks. David, the man to whom God gave such wonderful success; David, the anointed of the God of Jacob; David, sweet psalmist of Israel:

2.verse: The Spirit of the Lord spoke by me, And his word was on my tongue.

3.verse: The Rock of Israel said to me: ‘One shall come who rules righteously, Who rules in the fear of God.

4.verse: He shall be as the light of the morning; A cloudless sunrise When the tender grass Springs forth upon the earth; As sunshine after rain.’

5.verse: And it is my family He has chosen! Yes, God has made An everlasting covenant with me; His agreement is eternal, final, sealed. He will constantly look after My safety and success.

6.verse: But the godless are as thorns to be thrown away, For they tear the hand that touches them.

7.verse: One must be armed to chop them down; They shall be burned.”

8.verse: These are the names of the Top Three—the most heroic men in David’s army: the first was Josheb-basshebeth from Tahchemon, known also as Adino, the Eznite. He once killed eight hundred men in one battle.

9.verse: Next in rank was Eleazar, the son of Dodo and grandson of Ahohi. He was one of the three men who, with David, held back the Philistines that time when the rest of the Israeli army fled.

10.verse: He killed the Philistines until his hand was too tired to hold his sword; and the Lord gave him a great victory. (The rest of the army did not return until it was time to collect the loot!)

11.verse: After him was Shammah, the son of Agee from Harar. Once during a Philistine attack, when all his men deserted him and fled, he stood alone at the center of a field of lentils and beat back the Philistines; and God gave him a great victory.

13.verse: One time when David was living in the cave of Adullam and the invading Philistines were at the valley of Rephaim, three of the Thirty—the top-ranking officers of the Israeli army—went down at harvest time to visit him.

14.verse: David was in the stronghold at the time, for Philistine marauders had occupied the nearby city of Bethlehem.

15.verse: David remarked, “How thirsty I am for some of that good water in the city well!” (The well was near the city gate.)

16.verse: So the three men broke through the Philistine ranks and drew water from the well and brought it to David. But he refused to drink it! Instead, he poured it out before the Lord.

17.verse: “No, my God,” he exclaimed, “I cannot do it! This is the blood of these men who have risked their lives.”

18.verse: Of those three men, Abishai, the brother of Joab (son of Zeruiah), was the greatest. Once he took on three hundred of the enemy single-handed and killed them all. It was by such feats that he earned a reputation equal to the Three, though he was not actually one of them. But he was the greatest of the Thirty—the top-ranking officers of the army—and was their leader.

21.verse: Another time, armed only with a staff, he killed an Egyptian warrior who was armed with a spear; he wrenched the spear from the Egyptian’s hand and killed him with it.

1.verse: Once again the anger of the Lord flared against Israel, and he caused David to harm them by taking a national census. “Go and count the people of Israel and Judah,” the Lord told him.

2.verse: So the king said to Joab, commander-in-chief of his army, “Take a census of all the people from one end of the nation to the other, so that I will know how many of them there are.”

3.verse: But Joab replied, “God grant that you will live to see the day when there will be a hundred times as many people in your kingdom as there are now! But you have no right to rejoice in their strength.”

4.verse: But the king’s command overcame Joab’s remonstrance; so Joab and the other army officers went out to count the people of Israel.

5.verse: First they crossed the Jordan and camped at Aroer, south of the city that lies in the middle of the valley of Gad, near Jazer;

6.verse: then they went to Gilead in the land of Tahtim-hodshi and to Dan-jaan and around to Sidon;

7.verse: and then to the stronghold of Tyre, and all the cities of the Hivites and Canaanites, and south to Judah as far as Beersheba.

8.verse: Having gone through the entire land, they completed their task in nine months and twenty days.

9.verse: And Joab reported the number of the people to the king—800,000 men of conscription age in Israel and 500,000 in Judah.

10.verse: But after he had taken the census, David’s conscience began to bother him, and he said to the Lord, “What I did was very wrong. Please forgive this foolish wickedness of mine.”

11.verse: The next morning the word of the Lord came to the prophet Gad, who was David’s contact with God. The Lord said to Gad,

12.verse: “Tell David that I will give him three choices.”

13.verse: So Gad came to David and asked him, “Will you choose seven years of famine across the land, or to flee for three months before your enemies, or to submit to three days of plague? Think this over and let me know what answer to give to God.”

14.verse: “This is a hard decision,” David replied, “but it is better to fall into the hand of the Lord (for his mercy is great) than into the hands of men.”

15.verse: So the Lord sent a plague upon Israel that morning, and it lasted for three days; and seventy thousand men died throughout the nation.

16.verse: But as the death angel was preparing to destroy Jerusalem, the Lord was sorry for what was happening and told him to stop. He was by the threshing floor of Araunah the Jebusite at the time.

17.verse: When David saw the angel, he said to the Lord, “Look, I am the one who has sinned! What have these sheep done? Let your anger be only against me and my family.”

18.verse: That day Gad came to David and said to him, “Go and build an altar to the Lord on the threshing floor of Araunah the Jebusite.”

19.verse: So David went to do what the Lord had commanded him.

20.verse: When Araunah saw the king and his men coming toward him, he came forward and fell flat on the ground with his face in the dust.

21.verse: “Why have you come?” Araunah asked. And David replied, “To buy your threshing floor, so that I can build an altar to the Lord, and he will stop the plague.”

22.verse: “Use anything you like,” Araunah told the king. “Here are oxen for the burnt offering, and you can use the threshing instruments and ox yokes for wood to build a fire on the altar.

23.verse: I will give it all to you, and may the Lord God accept your sacrifice.”

24.verse: But the king said to Araunah, “No, I will not have it as a gift. I will buy it, for I don’t want to offer to the Lord my God burnt offerings that have cost me nothing.” So David paid him for the threshing floor and the oxen.

25.verse: And David built an altar there to the Lord and offered burnt offerings and peace offerings. And the Lord answered his prayer, and the plague was stopped.
